subject: Law
title: The International Court of Justice
description: A 60-second lesson on The International Court of Justice.

hook.text: Two countries dispute a border. Instead of going to war, they go to courtâ€”in The Hague.

buildup.text: The ICJ is the UN's principal judicial organ. It settles legal disputes between states and issues advisory opinions.

discovery.text: Only states can be parties in ICJ cases. Individuals and organizations cannot bring claims directly.

twist.text: Jurisdiction requires consent. If a state refuses to appear, the ICJ can still ruleâ€”but enforcement is another matter.

climax.text: The US ignored the ICJ ruling in Nicaragua v. United States (1986), showing the court's enforcement limits.

punchline.text: The World Court can judge. Making nations obey is the hard part.

quiz.question: Who can bring cases before the ICJ?
